variant.question: Just after rotation, the pilot accidentally retracts flaps instead of the landing gear. Which of the following is a possible outcome?

options.text: The aircraft may stall if the takeoff speed is below the clean configuration stall speed.
The aircraft will climb at a faster rate due to reduced drag in clean configuration.
The climb angle is increased but rate of climb is greatly reduced.
There is an increased risk of uncontrollable yaw moment.

variant.question: Ignoring downwash effects on the tailplane, extension of Fowler flaps, will produce:

options.text: a nose down pitching moment.
a nose up pitching moment.
a force which reduces drag.
no pitching moment.

variant.question: Due to a mechanical failure, the flaps are only extended in one of the wings. What will happen?

options.text: The aircraft will roll to the side where the flaps are not extended and yaw to the direction of the wing with extended flaps.
The aircraft will roll and yaw to the side where the flaps are not extended.
The aircraft will roll to the side where the flaps are extended and yaw to the same direction of the roll.
The aircraft will roll and yaw to the side where the flaps are extended.

variant.question: Wing spoilers are deflected symmetrically in flight in order to:

options.text: decelerate the aeroplane and/or increase its rate of descent.
assist the ailerons in obtaining a higher roll rate.
improve glide performance (increase lift /drag ratio).
prevent aeroplane yaw.

variant.question:
From an initial condition of level flight the flaps are retracted at a constant pitch attitude
 The aeroplane will subsequently

options.text: start to sink.
start to bank.
maintain level flight.
start to climb.

variant.question:
From an initial condition of level flight the flaps are extended at a constant pitch attitude
The aeroplane will subsequently

options.text: start to climb.
maintain level flight.
start to bank.
start to sink.

variant.question: When "spoilers" are used as speed brakes:

options.text: at the same angle of attack, CD is increased and CL is decreased.
for the same CL, the angle of attack must be reduced.
at the same angle of attack, CL remains unaffected.
the CL~MAX~ is not affected.

variant.question: Considering the effect of wing downwash on the direction of the airflow approaching the tailplane, when flaps are extended the tailplane’s negative angle of attack..

options.text: increases, increasing the tailplane’s effectiveness.
increases, decreasing the tailplane’s effectiveness.
decreases, decreasing the tailplane’s effectiveness.
decreases, increasing the tailplane’s effectiveness.

variant.question: When spoilers are used as speed brakes:

options.text: at same angle of attack, CD is increased and CL is decreased.
at same angle of attack, CL remains unaffected.
they do not affect wheel braking action during landing.
CLMAX of the polar curve is not affected.

variant.question: When spoilers are used as speed brakes:

options.text: at the same angle of attack, CD is increased and CL is decreased.
at the same angle of attack, CL remains unaffected.
the CLMAX is not affected.
for the same CL, the angle of attack must be reduced.

variant.question: Upward deflection of a trim tab in the longitudinal control results in

options.text: the stick position stability remaining constant.
increasing the stick force stability.
the stick force stability remaining constant.
increasing the stick position stability.

variant.question: Aileron reversal occurs when:

options.text: At high speed, when the downgoing aileron causes the wing to twist, forcing the leading edge down
At any speed, where the drag of the downgoing aileron causes yaw in the wrong direction.
At low speed, the downgoing aileron causes the wing to to twist at the wing tip, which reduces its angle of attack.
At low speed, the downgoing aileron increases angle of attack past its critical alpha.

variant.question: Flaps down...

options.text: increase drag and increase yaw.
increase lift and increase yaw.
increase lift and decrease yaw.
increase drag and decrease yaw.

variant.question:
Refer to figure. 
 X, Y and Z correspond to:

options.text: Angle of attack, climb angle, pitch angle.
Angle of attack, pitch angle, climb angle.
Pitch angle, climb angle, angle of attack.
Climb angle, pitch angle, angle of attack.

variant.question: A downward adjustment of a trim tab in the longitudinal control system, has the following effect

options.text: the stick position stability remains constant.
the stick force stability decreases.
the stick position stability increases.
the stick force stability remains constant.

variant.question: An aerodynamic balancing device, which makes it possible for a large surface to be deflected by a relatively small control force, is called

options.text: a servo tab.
a balance tab.
an anti-balance tab.
a horn balance.

variant.question: If the increased downwash at the tail plane due to lowering (extending) trailing edge flaps is considered in isolation:

options.text: a nose up pitching moment will be generated.
the direction of the pitch change will depend on the initial direction of the tail load.
tail plane angle of attack will be decreased, causing a nose down pitching moment.
a nose down pitching moment will be generated.

variant.question: Lowering the inboard flaps causes the wing CP:

options.text: to move inboard towards the wing root.
to move forward.
to move inward and forward.
to move outboard towards the wing tips.

variant.question: Refer to the wing downwash when the flaps are extended. What happens to the angle of attack of the tailplane and the tailplane effectiveness?

options.text: The negative angle of attack of the tailplane increases and the effectiveness of the tailplane increases.
The negative angle of attack of the tailplane decreases and the effectiveness of the tailplane decreases.
The negative angle of attack of the tailplane decreases and the effectiveness of the tailplane increases.
The negative angle of attack of the tailplane increases and the effectiveness of the tailplane decreases.

variant.question: Just after take-off, a pilot inadvertently retracts the flaps instead of the landing gear. What are the consequences?

options.text: The aeroplane will stall if the speed is lower than the stall speed in clean configuration.
The rate of climb will be increased as drag will be less than with take-off flaps.
The take-off may be continued normally as the aeroplane has already lifted-off.
None, because in accordance with the certification requirements, an interlock prevents retracting the flaps if the gear is down.

variant.question: (For this question use the image in the annex). Which of these statements about the pitching moment coefficient versus angle of attack lines in the annex is correct?

options.text: In its curved part at high angles of attack line 2 illustrates increasing static longitudinal stability.
Static longitudinal stability is greater at line 3 when compared with line 4 at low and moderate angles of attack.
The horizontal part of line 2 illustrates static longitudinal instability.
The CG position is further aft at line 4 when compared with line 1.

variant.question: Because the air flow will be coming from below the tailplane while manoeuvring, the aircraft will always have:

options.text:
More static longitudinal stability while
manoeuvring
More static longitudinal stability while S&L

Less static longitudinal stability while
manoeuvring

Less dynamic longitudinal stability while
manoeuvring

variant.question: What combined lateral/directional phenomenon can be caused by a yaw disturbance in the transonic speed range?

options.text: Dutch roll
Spiral divergence
Phugoid
Long period oscillation

variant.question: Consider a conventional aircraft with normal manoeuvring stability characteristics which does NOT require any augmentation. During initial climb, the elevator trim system remains stuck in the low speed regime with the aircraft’s control surfaces trimmed in the neutral position. The aircraft continues to climb at the same speed with the throttles fixed on the trimmed thrust setting. How will the stick force be experienced by the pilot during climb if the load factor is kept constant? The pilot will...

options.text: experience a decrease in stick force for a similar control surface deflection.
experience a slight increase in stick force, as at higher altitude and speed, less force is required for a similar control surface deflection.
NOT notice any change in stick force as the aircraft was trimmed neutral when the failure occurred.
experience an increase in stick force for a similar control surface the deflection.

variant.question: Pilot is trimming the aircraft during climb-out. At some point the trim gets stuck. Speed and power remain constant. What happens to stick force with increasing altitude?

options.text: Decreases
Stays the same
Increases and then decreases
Increases

variant.question:
Which of the following are reasons for trimming an aircraft in pitch?
1 changes of speed
2 Changes of power
3 Varying CG positions
4 Lateral displacement of CG

options.text: 1 and 4 only
1 and 2 only

variant.question: A forward CG shift:

options.text: increases static longitudinal stability.
has no influence on longitudinal manoeuvrability.
decreases static longitudinal stability.
increases longitudinal manoeuvrability.

variant.question: A forward CG shift:

options.text: decreases longitudinal manoeuvrability.
decreases static longitudinal stability.
has no influence on static longitudinal stability.
increases longitudinal manoeuvrability.

variant.question: The purpose of the horizontal stabilizer is to:

options.text: give the aeroplane sufficient longitudinal stability.
give the aeroplane enough weight in the tail area.
give the aeroplane sufficient lateral stability.
give the aeroplane sufficient directional stability.

variant.question: What happens if the CG is located beyond the forward CG limit?

options.text: This can lead to an unacceptably high value of manoeuvre stability.
This can lead to a lower than normal stick force during a normal rotation when taking off.
This can lead to much worse spin recovery characteristics
This can lead to a decreasing static longitudinal stability.

options.text: The CG position is further forward at line 4 when compared with line 1.

options.text: In its curved part at high angles of attack line 2 illustrates increasing static longitudinal stability.

variant.question: During the initial climb-out an airplane has its trim in the neutral position. As the aircraft continues to climb, the pilot realises that the aircraft's elevator trim is stuck in the low speed range. Knowing that the aircraft is climbing with trimmed thrust, the pilot may expect the stick forces to ...

options.text: decrease.
have a large increase, equal to the wanted control surface deflection.
slightly increase.
remain the same, because the failure happened in a neutral trim.

variant.question: What happens if the CG is further forward than what is entered into the FMS preflight?

options.text: Fuel consumption increases
Fuel consumption decreases
The elevator will be unable to correct for this error
Fuel consumption is not affected

variant.question: An aeroplane's bank angle is defined as the angle between its:

options.text: lateral axis and the horizontal plane.
longitudinal axis and the horizontal plane.
speed vector and the horizontal plane.
speed vector and longitudinal axis.

options.text: CG
Weight
Fuel Load
Thrust Settings

options.text: very high stick forces are required in pitch because the aircraft is very stable.
the longitudinal stability is reduced.
the stalling speed is reduced.

variant.question: When you pull the yoke backwards, what happens?

options.text: The elevator deflects up and increases the tailplanes negative angle of attack
The elevator deflects down and increases the tailplane’s negative angle of attack
The elevator deflects up and decreases the tailplanes negative angle of attack
The elevator deflects down and decreases the tailplane’s negative angle of attack

Elevator goes down and increase the tailplane positive angle of attack
Elevator goes down and increase the tailplanes negative angle of attack
Elevator goes up and increases the tailplanes positive angle of attack

increase with engines located on the rear fuselage.
decrease with engines located on the rear fuselage.
decrease with podded engines located beneath a low-mounted wing.

Which statement is correct?

I.  On fully hydraulic powered flight controls there is no need for mass balancing.

options.text: I is incorrect, II is correct.
I is correct, II is incorrect.
I is correct, II is correct.
I is incorrect, II is incorrect.

options.text: a servo tab.
a balance tab .
an anti-balance tab.

variant.question:
Where spoilers are used to assist ailerons with lateral control, when rolling to the right, the left aileron moves down and the right aileron moves up
How do the spoilers move?

options.text: The left spoilers remain flush and the right spoilers move up.
The right spoilers and the left spoilers remain flush.
The right spoilers and the left spoilers move up.
The left spoilers move up and the right spoilers remain flush.

variant.question: Where spoilers are used to assist ailerons with lateral control, when rolling to the right, the left aileron moves down and the right aileron moves up. How do the spoilers move?

options.text: The left spoilers remain flush and the right spoilers move up.
The right spoilers and the left spoilers move up.
The right spoilers and the left spoilers remain flush.
The left spoilers move up and the right spoilers remain flush.

options.text: changing the wing camber and the two wings therefore produce different lift values resulting in a moment about the longitudinal axis.
changing the wing drag and the two wings therefore produce different lift values resulting in a moment about the longitudinal axis.
causing sideslip, which generates a rolling moment.
aileron secondary effect.

variant.question: When a jet transport aeroplane takes off with the CG at the aft limit and the trimmable horizontal stabiliser (THS) is positioned at the maximum allowable nose down position for take-off:

options.text: rotation will be normal using the normal rotation technique.
rotation will require higher than normal stick force.
there will be a tendency to under-rotate.
early nose wheel raising will take place.

variant.question: Fairings of tail mounted engines give ___ pitching moment.

options.text: positive
negative or zero
zero
negative

constant spring tension to a trim system.
reduced control surface loads at all speeds.
feel feedback in a control system.

variant.question: A horn balance in a control system has the following purpose:

options.text: to decrease stick forces.
to prevent flutter.
to decrease the static longitudinal stability of the aeroplane.
to obtain mass balancing.

variant.question: A horn balance in a control system has the following purpose:

options.text: to decrease stick forces.
to decrease the effective longitudinal dihedral of the aeroplane.
to obtain mass balancing.
to prevent flutter.

variant.question: When power assisted controls are used for pitch control:

options.text: a part of the aerodynamic forces is still felt on the column.
trimming is superfluous.
aerodynamic balancing of the control surfaces is meaningless.
they only function in combination with an elevator trim tab.

variant.question: An airplane will be trimmed in pitch, due to: - Airspeed changes - Powersetting changes - Longitudinal centre of gravity (CG) changes - Lateral centre of gravity (CG) changes

Consider two aeroplanes: 
1. one with a trim tab2. the other fully powered hydraulic controls and an adjustable horizontal stabiliser. 
For both cases and starting from a trimmed condition, how will the neutral position of the control column change, after trimming for a speed increase?

options.text: 1 moves forward, 2 does not change.
1 does not change, 2 does not change.
1 moves forward, 2 moves forward.
1 does not change, 2 moves forward.

variant.question:
An aeroplane is provided with spoilers and both inboard and outboard ailerons
Roll control during cruise is provided by

outboard ailerons only.

options.text: Cruise.
Landing with a strong and gusty crosswind, to avoid over-controlling the aeroplane.
Approach.

variant.question: An aeroplane uses rudder aileron cross-coupling coupling to prevent adverse yaw. What happens if the aeroplane is rolled to the left?

options.text: The left aileron is deflected up, the right aileron is deflected down and the rudder is deflected to the left automatically.
The left aileron is deflected up, the right aileron is deflected down and the rudder is deflected to the right automatically.
The left aileron is deflected down, the right aileron is deflected up and the rudder is deflected to the right automatically.
The left aileron is deflected down, the right aileron is deflected up and the rudder is deflected to the left automatically.

variant.question: An aeroplane uses rudder aileron cross-coupling coupling to prevent adverse yaw. What happens if the aeroplane is rolled to the right?

options.text: The left aileron is deflected down, the right aileron is deflected up and the rudder is deflected to the right automatically.
The left aileron is deflected up, the right aileron is deflected down and the rudder is deflected to the left automatically.
The left aileron is deflected down, the right aileron is deflected up and the rudder is deflected to the left automatically.
The left aileron is deflected up, the right aileron is deflected down and the rudder is deflected to the right automatically.

options.text: the CG moves forward.
flaps are retracted at constant IAS.
IAS increases.
the CG moves aft.

options.text: the CG moves aft.
IAS decreases.
the CG moves forward.

variant.question: Flaperons are controls, which combine the function of

options.text: ailerons and flaps.
flaps and speed brakes.
flaps and elevator.
ailerons and elevator.

variant.question: When the CG position is moved aft, the elevator deflection to achieve an decrease in load factor will be:

larger.

variant.question: When the CG position is moved aft, the elevator deflection to achieve an increase in load factor will be:

options.text: smaller.
dependent on trim position.
unchanged.
larger.

variant.question: When comparing a stabiliser trim system with an elevator trim system, which of these statements is correct?

options.text: A stabiliser trim is less sensitive to flutter.
A stabiliser trim is not as capable to compensate large changes in pitching moments.
An elevator trim is more suitable for aeroplanes with a large CG range.
An elevator trim is able to compensate larger changes in pitching moments.

variant.question: When comparing an elevator trim system with a stabiliser trim system, which of these statements is correct?

options.text: An elevator trim system is more sensitive to flutter.
An elevator trim system is able to compensate larger changes in pitching moments.
An elevator trim system is more suitable for aeroplanes with a large CG range.
An elevator trim system is better adapted to larger flight speed ranges.

variant.question: When comparing an elevator trim system with a stabiliser trim system, which of these statements is correct?

options.text: an elevator trim is more sensitive to flutter.
an elevator trim is more suitable for aeroplanes with a large CG range.
an elevator trim is able to compensate larger changes in speed.
an elevator trim is able to compensate larger changes in pitching moments.

variant.question: When comparing an elevator trim system with a stabiliser trim system, which of these statements is correct?

options.text: An elevator trim is more sensitive to flutter.

variant.question: When comparing a stabiliser trim system with an elevator trim system, which of these statements is correct?

options.text: A stabiliser trim is able to compensate larger changes in pitching moments.
An elevator trim is able to compensate larger changes in pitching moments.

options.text: an elevator trim is less suitable for aeroplanes with a large CG range.
an elevator trim is able to compensate larger changes in airspeed.
a stabiliser trim is more sensitive to flutter.
an elevator trim is able to compensate larger changes in pitching moments.

variant.question: When comparing a stabiliser trim system with an elevator trim system, which of these statements is correct?

options.text: An elevator trim is less suitable for aeroplanes with a large CG range.
A elevator trim is able to compensate larger changes in pitching moments.
An elevator trim is able to compensate larger changes in pitching moments.

options.text: An elevator trim is less suitable for aeroplanes with a large cg range.
An elevator trim is able to compensate over a wider speed range.
A stabiliser trim is more sensitive to flutter.

options.text: larger.
smaller.
dependent on trim position.

variant.question: An aircraft is on final approach, fully configured and cleared to land when suddenly a vehicle enters the runway. The pilot decides to go-around, but realises that the stabiliser trim is jammed. What should the pilot do?

options.text: Go around but apply nose down pitch.
The pilot cannot go around.
Go around but apply nose up pitch.

variant.question: Which of these statements about a trimmable horizontal stabiliser is correct?

options.text: A trimmed aeroplane with an aft CG requires the stabiliser leading edge to be higher than in the case of a forward CG in the same condition.
At the aft CG limit, stabiliser trim is adjusted fully nose up to obtain maximum elevator authority at rotation during take-off.
A trimmed aeroplane with an aft CG requires the stabiliser leading edge to be lower than in the case of a forward CG in the same condition.
Because take-off speeds do not vary with CG position, the need for stabiliser adjustment is dependent on flap position only.

variant.question: Which of these statements about a trimmable horizontal stabiliser is correct?

options.text: A trimmed aeroplane with a forward cg requires the stabiliser leading edge to be lower than in the case of an aft cg in the same condition.
A trimmed aeroplane with a forward cg requires the stabiliser leading edge to be higher than in the case of an aft cg in the same condition.
Because take-off speeds do not vary with cg position, the need for stabiliser adjustment is dependent on flap position only.
At the forward cg limit, stabiliser trim is adjusted fully nose down to obtain maximum elevator authority at rotation during take-off.

variant.question: What should be usually done to perform a landing with the stabiliser jammed in the cruise flight position?

options.text: choose a higher landing speed than normal and/or use a lower flap setting for landing.
choose a lower landing speed than normal.
use the Mach trimmer until after landing.
if possible, relocate as many passengers as possible to the front of the cabin.

variant.question: What should be usually done to perform a landing with the stabilizer jammed in the cruise flight position?

options.text: Choose a higher landing speed than normal and/or use a lower flap setting for landing.

Choose a lower landing speed than normal.

variant.question: What is the fundamental difference between a trim tab and a servo tab?

options.text: The main purpose of a trim tab is to reduce stick force to zero in steady flight, a servo tab only reduces stick force.
A servo tab affects the stick force stability, whereas a trim tab does not.
The functioning of a trim tab is based on aerodynamic balancing, whereas a servo tab is usually adjusted via a screwjack.
A trim tab is automatically adjusted when its particular control surface moves, whereas a servo tab is moved independently of its particular control surface.

variant.question: What is the fundamental difference between a trim tab and a servo tab?

options.text: The purpose of a trim tab is to reduce continuous stick force to zero, a servo tab only reduces stick force.
A servo tab affects the stick force stability, whereas a trim tab does not.
The functioning of a trim tab is based on aerodynamic balancing, whereas a servo tab is usually adjusted via a screwjack.
A trim tab is automatically adjusted when its particular control surface moves, whereas a servo tab is moved independently of its particular control surface.

deflected down with the elevator in line with it.

(1) low, (2) locked, (3) geometric washout

variant.question:

Frise ailerons are used to reduce adverse aileron yaw

down-going aileron moves through a larger angle than the up-going aileron.
leading edge of the down-going aileron protrudes above the upper surface of the wing, causing more drag.

the pilot does not feel the stick forces at all.
mechanical adjustment of trim tabs creates too many problems.
trim tab deflection increases VMO.

trim tab deflection increases V~MO~.
the pilot does not feel the stick forces at all.

normal axis.

To reduce the directional stability at high airspeed.
To reduce the risk of entering a spiral divergence in cruise.

(1)down; (2) down; (3) left.
(1) up; (2) up; (3) right.
(1) up; (2) down; (3) left.

options.text: Elevator deflection is zero.
The elevator is always deflected slightly downward in order to have sufficient remaining flare capability.
The position depends on speed, the position of flaps and slats and the position of the centre of gravity.
At a forward CG, the elevator is deflected upward and at an aft CG, it is deflected downward.

variant.question: Explain why a full rudder deflection is limited on CAT transport aeroplanes as indicated airspeed increases?

options.text: A full rudder deflection could cause an excessive load on the structure of the aeroplane.
The statement is wrong since full rudder deflection is not limited with increasing airspeed.
To avoid any risk of entering a spiral during cruise flight.
To decrease the directional stability when the aeroplane is flying with high airspeeds.

1 does not change, 2 does not change.

variant.question: Which of the following is the correct example of differential aileron deflection to initiate a left turn?

options.text: Left aileron up 5° / right aileron down 2°.
Right aileron up 2° / left aileron down 5°.
Right aileron up 5° / left aileron down 2°.
Left aileron up 2° / right aileron down 5°.

variant.question: Concerning the differential aileron, the aileron with more deflection is...

options.text: the upward moving aileron.
the outer aileron.
the inner aileron.
the downward moving aileron.

variant.question: The purpose of a trim tab (device) is to:

options.text: reduce or to cancel control forces.
trim the aeroplane at low airspeed.
lower manoeuvring control forces.
trim the aeroplane during normal flight.

variant.question:
An adjustable trim tab, not linked to a balance tab,
will, as the main control is moved:

options.text: Not move relative to the main control
Move in the opposite sense to the main control
Return to neutral
Move in the same sense as the main control

variant.question: What is true about a Frise aileron?

options.text: It is an aileron where the leading edge protrudes below the wing when the aileron is raised, but not above it when the aileron is lowered.
It is an aileron where the leading edge protrudes above the wing when the aileron is lowered, but not below it when the aileron is raised.
It is an aileron where the deflection at the down going wing is lower than on the up going wing.
It is an aileron where the deflection at the up going wing is lower than on the down going wing.

variant.question: When comparing a trim tab with an anti-balance tab, which of the following statements is correct?  The trim tab

options.text: moves in the opposite direction to the control surface and the anti-balance tab moves in the same direction as the control surface.
is moved by pilot input and the anti-balance tab is moved by an electrical input.
increases control effectiveness and the anti-balance tab reduces it.
moves in the same direction as the control surface and the anti-balance tab moves in the opposite direction to the control surface.

variant.question: What is the main purpose of ailerons?

options.text: Changing rate of roll
Directional control
Changing bank angle
Pitch control

variant.question: If a pilot sets a trim setting for 12 % CG instead of 21 %, how could that influence the aircraft during the takeoff roll?

options.text: The aircraft will be tail heavy and stick force is reduced.
The aircraft will rotate normally and stick force is not affected.
The aircraft will not rotate.
The aircraft will be nose heavy and stick force is increased.

variant.question: Which statement about a jet transport aeroplane is correct, during take-off at the maximum allowable forward CG limit, while the THS (Trimmable Horizontal Stabilizer) has been positioned at the maximum allowable nose-down position?

options.text: The rotation will require extra stick force.
Nothing special will happen.
Early nose wheel raising will take place.
If the THS position is just within the limits of the green band, the take-off warning system will be activated.

variant.question: What should be usually done to perform a landing with the stabiliser trim jammed in the cruise position?

options.text: Move passengers aft / fly with a higher speed and less flap
Move passengers forward / fly with a lower speed and less flap
Move passengers aft / fly with a lower speed and full flap.
Move passengers forward / fly with a higher speed and less flap

variant.question: When the CG moves from the aft limit to the forward limit and the pilot wants to make a change in pitch:

options.text: manoeuvrability decreases due to static longitudinal stability.
manoeuvrability decreases due to dynamic longitudinal stability.
manoeuvrability decreases due to dynamic directional stability.
manoeuvrability decreases due to static lateral stability.

variant.question: The use of ailerons induces adverse (aileron) yaw. This occurs as a result of the...

options.text: up-going wing producing more drag than the down-going wing.
up-going wing being subjected to more aerodynamic damping than the down-going wing.
down-going wing producing more drag than the up-going wing.
up-going wing having a higher rate of roll when compared to the down-going wing.

variant.question: On an aircraft on which the ailerons are assisted by spoilers to give lateral control, if the control wheel is turned to the right:

options.text: the right aileron moves up, right spoiler up, left spoiler remains retracted, left aileron down.
the right aileron moves down, right spoiler up, left spoiler remains retracted, left aileron up.
the right aileron moves up, right spoiler remains retracted, left spoiler moves up, left aileron down.
the right aileron moves up, right spoiler up, left spoiler moves up only slightly, left aileron down.

variant.question: What is the advantage of a variable incidence tailplane over a fixed incidence tailplane with elevator and trim tab?

options.text: Less trim drag and maximum elevator authority retained.
Linkages and mechanism less complicated.
Increased flight stability and less weight.
Elevator movement is restricted at high speed.

variant.question: One of the main disadvantages of stabiliser trim system, compared to a conventional trim tab system, is that...

options.text: it is more complex and heavy.
the drag is greater in the trimmed state.
it is less powerful and gives a decreased ability to trim for larger CG ranges.
it reduces the effective range of pitch control.

variant.question: One of the main disadvantages of stabiliser trim system, compared to a conventional trim tab system, is that..

options.text: it is more complex and heavy.
it reduces the effective range of pitch control.
the drag is greater in the trimmed state.
it is less powerful and gives a decreased ability to trim for larger CG ranges.

variant.question: One of the main disadvantages of stabiliser trim system, compared to a conventional trim tab system, is that..

options.text: it is more complex and heavy.
it is less powerful and gives a decreased ability to trim for larger CG ranges.
the drag is greater in the trimmed state
it reduces the effective range of pitch control.

variant.question:
If a main control is jammed in flight a cockpit
adjustable trim tab will give:

options.text:
A small degree of control in opposite sense to
normal

A normal degree of control, but in opposite sense to
normal
A small degree of control in the normal sense
No control

variant.question: Deflecting the elevator up, when the trim tab is in neutral, will cause the tab to:

options.text: remain in line with the elevator.
remain in line with the tailplane.
move up relative to the elevator chord line.
move down relative to the elevator chord line.

variant.question: Aerodynamic balance can be obtained by:

options.text: an internal balance (the leading edge of the aileron is housed within a box inside the wing trailing edge, vented to atmosphere, with a seal from the wing to the leading edge of the aileron).
a weight mounted forward of the control surface hinge line.
the down-going aileron moving through a smaller angle than the up-going aileron.
an external balance, provided by a seal from the wing to the trailing edge of the aileron.

variant.question: A jet aeroplane equipped with inboard and outboard ailerons is cruising at its normal cruise Mach number. In this case:

options.text: only the inboard ailerons are active.
only the outboard aileron are active.
the inboard and outboard ailerons are active.
only the spoilers will be active, not the ailerons.

variant.question: To counter adverse yaw, an aircraft has aileron / rudder coupling. In a right turn, which of the following statements is true?

options.text: Left aileron goes down, right aileron goes up, and the rudder automatically moves to the right.
Left aileron goes up, right aileron goes down, and the rudder automatically moves to the right.
Left aileron goes up, right aileron goes down, rudder automatically moves to the left.
Left aileron goes down, right aileron goes up, and the rudder automatically moves to the left.

variant.question: Comparing the differences between a horizontal trimmable stabiliser and an elevator trim tab which of these statements are correct or incorrect?
firstCorrectStatements: A trim tab is less suitable for jet transport aeroplanes because of their large speed range.
When trimmed for zero elevator stick force an elevator trim tab causes more drag.
A stabiliser trim is more suitable to cope with the large trim changes generated by the high lift devices on most jet transport aeroplanes.
firstIncorrectStatements: When trimmed for zero elevator stick force a horizontal trimmable stabiliser causes more drag.
The effects of a trim tab runaway are more serious.
When trimmed for zero elevator stick force a horizontal trimmable stabiliser causes more drag.
An elevator trim tab is more suitable to cope with the large trim changes generated by the high lift devices on most jet transport aeroplanes.
secondCorrectStatements: A stabiliser trim is a more powerful means of trimming.
A horizontal trimmable stabiliser enables a larger CG range.
A trim tab runaway causes less control difficulty.
The effects of a stabiliser trim runaway are more serious
A jammed trim tab causes less control difficulty.
secondIncorrectStatements: An elevator trim tab enables a larger CG range.
A jammed stabiliser trim causes less control difficulty.
An elevator trim tab enables a larger CG range.
A stabiliser trim runaway causes less control difficulty.

variant.question: Aileron reversal can be caused by:

options.text: twisting of the wing above reversal speed.
neither answer is correct.
frise type ailerons at low angles of attack.
both answers are correct.

variant.question:
This question does not apply to students of the new 2020 Syllabus
Aileron flutter can be caused by:

options.text: cyclic deformations generated by aerodynamic, inertial and elastic loads on the wing.
aileron reversal.
continuous deformations in one direction generated by bending and twisting of the wing.
the elastic centre of the wing section coinciding with the centre of gravity of that wing section.

variant.question: Which of the below are not aerodynamic balances

options.text: Mass balance
Horn balance
Inset hinge
Internal seal

variant.question: Aileron reversal may be caused by:

options.text: the wing twisting and reducing incidence when the aileron is lowered.
the wing twisting and increasing incidence when the aileron is lowered.
the wing twisting and reducing incidence when the aileron is raised.
the aileron being pushed in the reverse direction by aileron drag.

variant.question: Aileron flutter can be reduced by:

options.text: Mass balancing of the aileron by adding weight ahead of the hinge line and reducing speed
Aerodynamic balancing of the aileron by moving the hinge line into the aileron and reducing speed
Aerodynamic balancing the aileron by moving the hinge line ahead of the aileron and reducing speed
Mass balancing of the aileron by adding weight behind the hinge line and reducing speed

variant.question:
Which statements are correct or incorrect?
1) On fully hydraulic powered flight controls there is no need for mass balancing.
2) On fully hydraulic powered flight controls there is no need for trim tabs.

options.text: 1) is incorrect; 2) is correct.
1) is correct; 2) is correct.
1) is incorrect; 2) is incorrect.
1) is correct; 2) is incorrect.

variant.question: Aileron flutter can be caused by:

options.text: cyclic deformations generated by aerodynamic, inertial and elastic loads on the wing.
the elastic centre of the wing section coinciding with the centre of gravity of that wing section.
aileron reversal.
continuous deformations in one direction generated by bending and twisting of the wing.

variant.question: Angle "Y" in the diagram corresponds to the:

options.text: Pitch or blade angle.
Advance or helix angle.
Slipstream angle.
Blade angle of attack.

variant.question: During the take-off roll, when the pilot raises the tail in a tail wheeled, clockwise (seen from pilot's perspective) rotating propeller driven aeroplane , a strong left yaw is generated, forcing the pilot to apply almost full right rudder to keep the aeroplane on the centreline. Before the tail is raised, the left yaw is caused by (I) and after the tail is raised the left yaw is caused by (II).

options.text: (I) spiralling slipstream; (II) gyroscopic precession
(I) gyroscopic precession; (II) asymmetric blade effect
(I) spiralling slipstream; (II) asymmetric blade effect
(I) torque reaction; (II) asymmetric blade effect

variant.question:
Refer to figure.  
  X, Y and Z in order of corresponds to:

options.text: Helix angle, blade angle, angle of attack.
Blade angle, helix angle, angle of attack.
Angle of attack, helix angle, blade angle.
Helix angle, angle of attack, blade angle.

variant.question: In asymmetric flight, yawing towards the live engine gives a sideslip force on the fuselage side...

options.text: behind the CG and opposite to the rudder force.
forward of the CG and opposite to the rudder force.
forward of the CG and similar to the rudder force.
behind the CG and similar to the rudder force.

variant.question:
Which of the following statements is correct?

1. VMCL is the minimum control speed in the landing configuration.

2. The speed VMCL is always limited by maximum rudder deflection.

options.text: I is correct, II is incorrect.
I is correct, II is correct.
I is incorrect, II is correct.
I is incorrect, II is incorrect.

variant.question:
Which of these statements about the limiting value of 5 degrees bank angle during V~MCA~ determination are correct or incorrect?

1.  When the bank angle is decreased from 5 degrees to 0 degrees, the value of V~MCA~
 will remain approximately constant.

2. At any bank angle above 5 degrees, V~MCA~ will decrease correspondingly.

options.text: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.
I is correct, II is correct.
I is incorrect, II is correct.
I is correct, II is incorrect.

variant.question:
Which of the following statements are correct or incorrect?
1) When the critical engine fails during take-off the speed V~MCL~ can be limiting.
2) The speed V~MCL~ is always limited by maximum rudder deflection.

options.text: A tailwind with constant aeroplane mass compared with zero wind.
A headwind with constant aeroplane mass compared with zero wind.
An increase in aeroplane mass in zero wind.
A decrease in aeroplane mass in zero wind.

variant.question: If the tailplane is required to give a down force in level flight the fuel burn will be

options.text:
More than it would be if the tailplane gave an up
force
Depends on the position of the CG

Less than it would be if the tailplane gave an up
force

Fuel burn is not affected by the force produced by the
tailplane

variant.question:
T- Tail is ____________ stable than a conventional because they receive __________
 downwash

options.text: MORE / LESS
LESS / MORE
LESS / LESS
MORE / MORE

variant.question: During flight testing, the minimum control speeds are established. The V~MCG~ must be established with (1) _____ CG position and (2) _____ the use of nose wheel steering.

options.text: (1) most unfavorable; (2) without
(1) forward; (2) without
(1) most unfavorable; (2) with
(1) forward; (2) with
